results.title: Requiem by Andrew Lloyd Webber
results.creator_credit: Ian Squires, BBC-TV, The Really Useful Group and Humphrey Burton
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at the St Thomas Church, New York, on Sunday February 24th 1985, the world premiere of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Requiem” was performed to an enthusiastic and receptive audience. The wonderful voices of Placido Domingo (tenor), Sarah Brightman (soprano) and Paul Miles-Kingston (treble) supported by the Winchester Cathedral Choir (directed by Martin Neary), The St Thomas Choir (directed by Gerre Hancock) and the Orchestra of St Luke’s conducted by Lorin Maazel give depth and quality to Webber’s original composition.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Squires, BBC-TV, The Really Useful Group and Humphrey Burton

results.title: Repulsion motor principles
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of Education and Ray-Bell Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Electrical work: electrical machinery”.
Explains construction of repulsion motor, rotor circuits and effects of brush position; short-circuiting and brush-lifting mechanism; and application of repulsion motors. This film is a technical training film on the design and construction of repulsion brush type electric A.C. motors as used in the first half of this century.

results.title: Republic of virtue
results.creator_credit: James Kent, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “American visions”.
In this first program of the series, Robert Hughes announces his intention to look at America through the lens of its visual culture and to see what we can tell about the American experience through the things Americans have made. The program charts the foundation of American identity following the War of Independence and ends on the eve of the American Civil War. The dominance of neo-classicism as a style which would imbue the nation with age-old values came to rule the aesthetics behind the building of Washington, D. C. America’s first major architect, Thomas Jefferson, is profiled with sequences at his home in Monticello and The University of Virginia, both of which he designed. The capital’s monuments to George Washington and Lincoln echo the need for authority, carried through in minimalist form today by the Vietnam Memorial designed by Maya Lin. The work of the nation’s first major painters; Benjamin West, John Singleton Copley, and Charles Willson Peale is outlined and the paintings in the Capitol Building are described. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Republic day: India
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: The celebrations in Delhi on India’s national day, 26th January. The President drives in State to take the salute at a parade of armed forces, floats representing the various provinces and industries, folk dances and marching schoolchildren. Illuminations and fireworks enliven the city at night. The following day a fold dance festival shows the dances of many districts. The military ceremony of Beating the Retreat concludes the festivities.

results.title: Republic Day, 1955
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The pageantry witnessed in the capital on Republic Day. Colorful tableaux representing the achievements and developments of the national plans in different areas, the spectacular parade of the three units of the Armed Forces, and a brilliant display of fireworks.

results.title: Reptiles: a first film
results.creator_credit: George J. Holland, Norman Bean Films and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Introduces basic information about the characteristics of reptiles: body temperature, skin types and habitats. Shows various reptiles in their natural environment including alligators, turtles, snakes and chameleons. Provides a recapitulation of the information presented. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Reptiles of Western Australia
results.brief_description: Reptiles of four different types are shown: snakes, lizards, tortoises and turtles, land crocodiles, which are found in Western Australia. All are cold-blooded, and need the sun to warm them and encourage them to move. Close-up shots reveal the features of each type; the turtle’s skeleton attached to its hard back; fascinating lizards with frills, spikes or blue tongues; snakes’ markings and their fangs in action; fresh-water, harmless crocodiles and flesh-eaters which live in salt water.

results.title: Reptiles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
Australia has some of the most interesting reptiles in the world. There are giant crocodiles, beautiful sea turtles and a variety of bizarre lizards, including the amazing Frilled Lizard. Even more remarkable are the snakes. Nine out of the ten most venomous snakes in the world are Australian. Included is rare footage of the recently discovered Small Scaled Snake. Narrated by David Moore.

results.title: Reproductive technology: facts and issues
results.creator_credit: Environment Audio Visuals, Neil Barrett and Jonathan Pearl
results.brief_description: This video is designed for students in years 10-12. Part one looks at recent technological advances in the field of reproduction and Part two raises some of the legal and ethical issues involved in such technology.

results.title: Reproductive system. - 2nd. ed.
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Media and Instant Miracles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human Body”.
Part of a series which comprehensively covers the major systems of the body. This episode examines the functions of the reproductive system in the male and female. Diagrammatic animation illustrates how pituitary hormones control and the maturation and functioning of the organs and how they in turn make reproduction possible through the union of egg and sperm.
